Title: Looking for examples of Discrete / Continuous complementary approaches
AcceptedAnswer: I like the following problem: Decompose a positive integer $N$ into positive integer addends summing to $N$ with maximal product. In the "discrete" version of this problem, you find that the answer is almost to use all $3$ s; but, not every positive integer is a sum of $3$ s, so you might need some $2$ s to finish it off. Unsurprisingly, then, the "continuous" analog of a problem solved discretely by mostly- $3$ s-with-a-few- $2$ s involves $e$ . The benefit of $3$ over $2$ is easy to see by decomposing $6$ , for which $3 \cdot 3 = 9 > 8 = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2$ . For a couple of references to this particular problem, see: Krause, E. F. (1996). Maximizing the product of summands; minimizing the sum of factors. Mathematics Magazine, 69(4), 270-278. Wasserman, N. H. (2014). A rationale for irrationals: An unintended exploration of e. Mathematics Teacher, 107(7), 500-507. For a student-friendly version, see the link on PlayWithYourMath :
